title: I need help with my APA citations for my research paper. Are they correct? - Quora

response.answer_text: For some reason I can’t see your references. I can see the ones below by Crystal Kim. I’m going to take them and fix them and post as a photo for you. Crystal, I mean no insult, I just couldn’t find the original post. Anyway, I did the first few. The yellow areas are the changes I made. You can check them against the original if you don’t understand what they were. All APA documents now require a digital object identifier (if it exists for the document). You have to pull up the actual document, NOT just the Google Scholar reference, to get the DOI. You can use one of two forms for the doi, either the way I have it in the picture below, or as an http://doi. etc link. However, if you start off doing it one way you have to keep doing it that way. Right now the way it is written is in flux; APA is supposed to come out with a firm rule in the next six months or so. The point is, it has to be there if it exists. So no more “Retrieved from www.thomaswilson.edu.pa” if it is an academic document.

Benson, K., Suter, R. B. (2013). Reflections on the tapetum lucidum and eyeshine in Lycosoid spiders. Journal of Arachnology, 41(1), 43-52. Clemente, C. J., McMaster, K. A., Fox, E., Meldrum, L., Stewart, T., Main, B. Y. (2010). The visual system of the Australian wolf spider Lycosa leuckartii (Araneae: Lycosidae): visual acuity and the functional role of the eyes. Journal of Arachnology, 38(3), 398-406. Flick, A. J., Acevedo, M. A., Elderd, B. D. (2016). The negative effects of pathogen-infected prey on predators: a meta-analysis. Oikos, 125(11), 1554-1560. Joern, A., Danner, B. J., Logan, J. S., Wolesensky, W. (2006). Natural history of mass-action in predator-prey models: a case study from wolf spiders and grasshoppers. The American Midland Naturalist, 156(1), 53-64.
